docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint, the nation's largest health insurance provider, said Wednesday that its profit more than doubled as it reported the first full-quarter results after its $16.5 billion merger of the two largest Blue Cross-Blue Shield providers. WellPoint, based in Indianapolis, earned $611.7 million, or $1.97 a share, in the first quarter, compared with $295.6 million, or $2.08 a share, in the year-earlier period, when it operated as Anthem.
docs.snippet: INDIANAPOLIS, April 27 (AP) - WellPoint, the nation's largest health insurance provider, said Wednesday that its profit more than doubled as it reported the first full-quarter results after its $16.5 billion merger of the two largest Blue Cross-Blue...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional negotiations to break an impasse over the federal budget hit a major stumbling block on Wednesday, when an influential Republican senator walked away from the talks amid a dispute with the White House and the Republican leadership over Medicaid spending. The senator, Gordon H. Smith of Oregon, has told the leadership that he is now prepared to vote against the budget, a spokesman said. The majority leader, Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, had hoped to bring the $2.57 trillion budget measure to the Senate floor for a vote on Friday; a spokesman said Wednesday evening he planned to stick to that schedule.

headline.main: Oregon Republican in Revolt Over Budget

docs.abstract: Congressional negotiations to break impasse over federal budget hit major stumbling block when Sen Gordon H Smith, influential Republican, walks away from talks amid dispute with White House and Republican leadership over Medicaid spending; Smith spearheaded drive to eliminate reductions in growth of spending on Medicaid and instead to create commission to study future of program; but White House and Republican leadership promised during last year's election campaign to bring spending under control; whether budget measure can pass in Senate without Smith's support is unclear (M)
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 27 - Congressional negotiations to break an impasse over the federal budget hit a major stumbling block on Wednesday, when an influential Republican senator walked away from the talks amid a dispute with the White House and the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the hospital operator, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was considering filing civil charges against it over its financial reporting of Medicare reimbursements. Tenet, based in Dallas, said it had received a so-called Wells notice from the S.E.C. staff regarding the adequacy of its disclosures of Medicare reimbursements under managed care contracts for certain cases. Such notices signal that S.E.C. staff members intended to recommend S.E.C. enforcement action. Tenet, which first disclosed an S.E.C. inquiry in April 2003, is being scrutinized for how it charged the Medicare program for treating the sickest patients.

headline.main: TENET RECEIVES NOTICE THAT IT MAY FACE S.E.C. CHARGES

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission is considering filing civil charges against it over its financial reporting of Medicare reimbursements (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new president was officially installed at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey on Tuesday, at a time when the school faces mounting questions about its financial practices, including the awarding of millions of dollars in bonuses to top officials and the spending of millions more on no-bid contracts. John J. Petillo, who was appointed in November and had been interim president since June, was sworn in as the school's third president at a ceremony attended by about 2,400 people at the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts.

headline.main: New Leader At University In Newark

docs.snippet: John J. Petillo, who was appointed in November and had been interim president since June, was sworn in as the school's third president on Tuesday.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: UNIVERSITY OF MEDICINE AND DENTISTRY OF NEW JERSEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in Congress said Tuesday that they were near agreement with the White House on a proposal to break an impasse over the federal budget by setting up a commission on the future of Medicaid and by cutting the growth of the program by $10 billion over the next five years. Administration officials and Republican leaders in Congress said they hoped that a deal on Medicaid would clear the way for a broader agreement on the contours of the federal budget -- a budget resolution, in the language of Capitol Hill. The House and Senate last month passed competing versions of a $2.57 trillion budget for 2006, but spokesmen for the budget committees in both chambers said Tuesday night that they were close to reconciling those differences.

headline.main: Medicaid Panel Described As Near Key Budget Deal

docs.snippet: Administration officials and Republican leaders in Congress said they hoped that a deal on Medicaid would clear the way for a broader agreement on the federal budget.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN as the nation's health care costs keep climbing, the insurance companies that try to manage those costs have been prospering and increasing their profit. But some analysts see trouble ahead. The share prices of three of the largest insurers -- WellPoint, UnitedHealth Group and Cigna -- reached 52-week highs early this month, at the peak of a two-year surge in the stocks of managed care companies. But since April 7, the big insurers have led the way down as a Standard & Poor's index of managed care stocks fell 8.4 percent while the broader S.&P. 500-stock index slipped only 3.3 percent.

headline.main: The notable prosperity of managed care plans may already be tapering off, some analysts say.

docs.abstract: Some analysts believe prosperity of managed care plans may be tapering off; share prices of WellPoint, UnitedHealth Group and Cigna reached 52-week highs early in month, at peak of two-year surge in stocks of managed care companies; but since April 7, big insurers have led way down as Standard & Poor's index of managed care stocks fell 8.4 percent while broader S&P 500-stock index dropped only 3.3 percent; enrollment growth is slowing, and effect of Medicare drug coverage is unclear (Market Place column) (M)
docs.snippet: Even as health care costs keep climbing, the insurance companies that try to manage those costs have been prospering, but some analysts see trouble ahead.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'm not normally much of a television viewer, but while I was recovering from painful surgery, watching TV for several hours a night was a welcome distraction, though not always enough. Every 10 or 15 minutes, it seemed, some screen personality was urging me to ask my doctor about one drug or another. In two months of watching programs from 9 to 11 p.m., I was treated to scores of advertisements for about two dozen prescription drugs intended to treat ailments common to 21st-century Americans.

headline.main: Can Bob Dole Save Your Life? Ask Your Doctor

docs.snippet: Is television telling you to "ask your doctor"? Well, what if your doctor doesn't know?

docs.lead_paragraph: They are literally attached at the hip. Montefiore Medical Center, a prosperous nonprofit institution, and North Central Bronx Hospital, a small city-run center, share not only their Norwood neighborhood, but also a connecting walkway and some specialists. Many of Montefiore's staff even prefer North Central Bronx's cafeteria. The cheek-by-jowl existence has for years prompted skepticism about the need for North Central Bronx, the smallest of the 11 centers in the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation network. With a hospital-closing commission taking shape in Albany, such talk has only escalated among analysts, industry representatives and others who say privately that North Central Bronx could be vulnerable.

headline.main: Forget Close Competition. This Is Next-Door Rivalry.

docs.snippet: They are literally attached at the hip. Montefiore Medical Center, a prosperous nonprofit institution, and North Central Bronx Hospital, a small city-run center, share not only their Norwood neighborhood, but also a connecting walkway and some...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Liam Cregan got a call from the Irish Consulate in New York on March 15, telling him that his wife, Kathleen Kelly Cregan, was in critical condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, he thought it had to be a mistake, that someone had stolen her passport. Mrs. Cregan had left her home in rural Ireland two days before, telling her husband, a farmer and part-time plumber, that she would be attending a business course in Dublin.

headline.main: The Irish Patient And Dr. Lawsuit

docs.snippet: A death after a cosmetic surgery brings more attention to a surgeon with a tarnished record full of malpractice suits.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEW YORK EYE AND EAR INFIRMARY

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Alan Schiller's 87-year-old mother died in January, ''it took some convincing,'' Schiller says, to get his siblings to agree to an autopsy. ''They said: 'She had Alzheimer's. Let her rest.' But I told them: 'No, something seems funny to me. An autopsy is the only way to be sure.''' Schiller prevailed. A tanned, quick-minded, gregarious man in his 60's, he is naturally persuasive, and as chairman of pathology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, he carries a certain authority regarding autopsies. The word ''autopsy,'' he reminded his siblings, means to ''see for oneself,'' and they should see what happened to their mother. Schiller's mother died in Miami, so he called his friend Dr. Robert Poppiti Jr., chairman of pathology at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. She was on the table the next morning. In a living patient, Alzheimer's is a diagnosis of exclusion, one that should ideally be reached only by eliminating all testable causes of fading memory and mind. Confirming it requires directly examining the brain. The definitive markers are the tiny protein plaques and fibrous tangles that appear under the microscope in stained sections. But a good pathologist can spot advanced Alzheimer's just by looking at the whole brain. The brain will be shorter, front to back, and more squarish than normal -- a reflection of Alzheimer's neuronal decimation, which shrinks the brain up to 15 percent. This would presumably have been the case with Mrs. Schiller. But the autopsist found her brain of normal shape and size. Dissecting it, he discovered a half-dozen cystlike lesions scattered throughout -- areas darker, softer and less elastic than the buff-colored parts surrounding them.
docs.snippet: Routine hospital autopsies have come to be seen as a waste of time. But the dead have much to tell us about treating and preventing disease.
